ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: It was a Zoom class, sometimes discussion and sometimes lecture. Also sometimes focused on group work in breakout rooms
We would occasionally have live virtual lectures.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to construct a research question, review relevant literature, create a research design, and conduct a research study. I also learned how to write all of that into a research paper.

This class made me think a lot about how to conduct different types of experiments and the work that goes into writing them up. I learned how to write a scientific psychology paper, which is a super useful skill I've already used in several of other courses.
Writing research papers, conducting literature reviews, Qualtrics, statistics practice in SPSS

I learned how to format and write up research papers for psychology in a detailed and coherent manner. I learned what the steps are for designing experiments, carrying them out, collecting data, and analyzing data. I also furthered the knowledge I gained from my statistics course by actually applying it to studies we carried out in class.
A broad overview of research methods used in psychology as well as hands-on experience developing and reporting on two small studies

This course covered how to conduct psychology research using both theoretical and practical approaches. I gained hands-on research experiences with the two studies we conducted in class and developed skills such as hypothesis forming, study design, data collection, data analysis, research report writing, and more.
How to write a psychology research paper, start to finish, and how to properly collect and analyze data
I learned how to conduct research and write a formal report.
I learned how to write scientifically, including how to write research papers. I also learned how to design and conduct my own psychological experiments and how to search the literature.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I loved Professor Gendron. She's amazing and always so ready to help students. Strengths include the grace days, the reading quizzes, and only one exam which was open note. I liked the optional draft options for the final paper.

I really liked the textbook and the online quiz format. I also received really good feedback on my papers, which was great! I think the main drawback of the course was that the instructions for the papers were sometimes very confusing, and it was hard to keep track of all of them. It was also difficult to know what information to include on the final paper, as we discussed so many different things, but I think Professor Gendron was pretty lenient, especially with the stats sections, which is great.
Strengths were the set up of the course and the papers we wrote

strengths: the content was always taught in a straightforward and detailed manner

weaknesses: sometimes the textbook chapters felt irrelevant to class discussions/in-class content; there was also a lot of work cramped into the first half of the semester, and much less in the second half (the distribution of work felt lopsided/unequal)
Very strong course in general, very engaging

Strengths: good hands-on experience and you get to pick topics you're interested in; lectures and textbook all covered very helpful materials; Prof. Gendron and our TF were really available, patient, and warm
Weaknesses: As part of the course design, we received less feedback on the 2nd research project. But since our class study (the 2nd project) was much more complicated than the group study (the first project), I wish we had spent more time debriefing it.

i appreciated that there were earlier deadlines for larger assignments to receive feedback on our drafts. as a procrastinator, it helped me stay on track throughout the semester and also gave me the opportunity to revise and edit my assignments. it got overwhelming at times to have so many things due for one class (there were a lot of smaller tasks we needed to complete before each class along with the larger assignment, along with class readings we would have to do on our own time), but overall i think the prof and TF were pretty helpful in answering any questions and pushing back deadlines at certain points of the semester (i.e. the presidential election) if we as a class were feeling overwhelmed.
Really amazing and intriguing!
Professor and TA were very involved in student success. I can suggest no improvements.

I really liked that the class provided us with a baseline. I hadn't had much experience with scientific writing or with conducting experiments, and this course helped me get the baseline that I needed. The professor didn't assume that students had any prior knowledge, which was super awesome. I liked the material that we covered (we specifically talked about how WASPy psychological research is). We also got lots of feedback on our writing, which was super helpful even if it was shocking at first to see the amount of comments on your page. The textbook was helpful, although it contained so much information that I wish we had covered some of it in class. We were expected to read the textbook and take quizzes on it, which was helpful but we never got to apply the information we learned to what we were doing in class. The quizzes and the one exam were good ways to test what I had learned, although the amount of reading and work this class had was often overwhelming. It was especially frustrating when we'd get assigned lots of work and then it wasn't graded until the end of the semester. Because there was so much work, I sometimes felt like I didn't absorb the important information as much as I'd have liked to. For example, we did two in-class exercises on SPSS, but we mostly worked on these independently, and I would've liked a class with the professor orienting us in SPSS instead of the worksheet. When I analyzed data one-on-one with the professor and a few other students, I understood what we were doing and why; when we did the in-class assignments earlier in the semester, I had no idea what our results meant or what we were really doing. It would've been helpful to have some orientation in this aspect and to have it applied practically, since a lot of this class doesn't make sense if it's not applied practically. I just feel like a lot of those in-class assignments should have had some more guidance from the professor.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great flexibility with what the class needed.

The online format actually worked pretty well with this course. Obviously, being in person might have made discussion easier, but I think that Dr. Gendron was able to adapt really well, and used Zoom to her advantage whenever possible.
breakout rooms succeeded well, teacher needs to work on not lecturing the whole time during the zoom call because it does not help learning
Not sure what exact practices were put towards virtual learning but things seemed to work well in this course :)

The synchronous virtual seminars and lectures worked out nicely, but I hoped we had posted more class recordings for reviews, especially towards the later half of the semester. Since many of the hands-on research parts in this class are new to many, a platform for classmates to ask general questions outside of class time might be helpful.
Lots of pollEv and office hours/stats clinics and workshops to take full advantage of all resources offered to us! No pressure to answer questions, but an open and inviting environment to do so

I think this class was, for the most part, well-adapted to the online format given that if we weren't having lectures, we would be working independently or working in small groups on our projects with assistance from the professor and the TA. I would have liked it if there were more ways that the professor engaged with students during the lecture portions because I often found it difficult to focus (the class was 9am EST and 8am for me). The TA held a really engaging lecture but that was on the last day of class, so maybe in the future, it'd be cool if the TA could lead some of the lectures as well. Maybe the lectures could also make use of more Zoom features, such as surveys. I really liked it when the professor would ask us questions that we'd answer in some kind of app as the lecture went along. I also feel like considering that we were in a global pandemic and people's mental health was not in the best spot, the course load for this class was a lot, especially because a lot of the work was what I'd consider to be busy work. I often didn't see how the in-class assignments applied practically to our research until I sat with the professor and we walked through them together. There was already a distance due to us being online, and I think the class could've done a better job of lessening that feeling of isolation. I often felt very disconnected from my classmates even when we were in breakout rooms together. I think having more class engagement could really help that.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely! Especially for psych majors, this really helped me feel comfortable in the major.
Yes, definitely. I gained lots of really practical knowledge that I will definitely use in the future!

Yes! This was a great course. The amount of work is very manageable, and I didn't feel like it was busywork. I also loved having the opportunity to submit drafts of our papers and receive feedback and feel that it allowed my writing to improve a lot. In addition, the practice using SPSS and statistics was super helpful, and Dr. Gendron was very understanding of people with different levels of prior stats knowledge.

if you're a psychology major, yes, because you have to take this course 
if you are a non-psych major, there may be other research methods courses geared more towards your interests than this one
Of course most people take this course as a requirement but it is definitely enjoyable, especially with Professor Gendron

Yes! You do learn a lot about research methods, and it's especially helpful for those who would like to work in psych research labs. Prof. Gendron and Srishti (TF) are both very patient and knowledgeable.
it's a requirement for psychology majors, so i don't see people voluntarily taking this course. but as to taking research methods with specifically prof. gendron, i would recommend!
Definitely take this course! A really fun research methods course. We answered a research question that was very relevant today for our final paper
Absolutely. Dr. Gendron is a fantastic instructor!

I don't know why you'd take it if you weren't majoring in psych, but you do you! If you are in psych, even though this is a required course, I'd say that you'll get a lot out of it, especially if you're anxious because you feel like you don't have enough research experience.
